text: 1. There lived once upon a time G âna s ruti Pautrâya n a (the great-grandson of G ana s ruta), who was a pious giver, bestowing much wealth upon the

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: people, and always keeping open house. He built places of refuge everywhere, wishing that people should everywhere eat of his food.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. Once in the night some Ha m sas (flamingoes) flew over his house, and one flamingo said to another: 'Hey, Bhallâksha, Bhallâksha (short-sighted friend). The light (glory) of G âna s ruti Pautrâya n a has spread like the sky. Do not go near, that it may not burn thee.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. The other answered him: 'How can you speak of him, being what he is (a râ g anya, noble), as if he were like Raikva with the car 1 ?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. The first replied: 'How is it with this Raikva with the car of whom thou speakest?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: The other answered: 'As (in a game of dice) all the lower casts 2 belong to him who has conquered with the K ri ta cast, so whatever good deeds other people perform, belong to that Raikva. He who knows what he knows, he is thus spoken of by me.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5. G âna s ruti Pautrâya n a overheard this conversation, and as soon as he had risen in the morning, he said to his. door-keeper (kshatt ri ): 'Friend, dost thou speak of (me, as if I were) Raikva with the car?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: He replied: 'How is it with this Raikva, with the car?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 6. The king said: 'As (in a game of dice), all the lower casts belong to him who has conquered with the K ri ta cast, so whatever good deeds other people perform, belong to that Raikva. He who knows what he knows, he is thus spoken of by me.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 7. The door-keeper went to look for Raikva, but returned saying, 'I found him not.' Then the king said: 'Alas! where a Brâhma n a should be searched for (in the solitude of the forest), there go for him.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 8. The door-keeper came to a man who was lying beneath a car and scratching his sores 1 . He addressed him, and said: 'Sir, are you Raikva with the car? '

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: He answered: 'Here I am.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Then the door-keeper returned, and said: 'I have found him.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 55:2 Vâyu (air) and Prâ n a (breath) had before been represented as feet of Brahman, as the second pair. Now they are represented as Brahman, and as to be meditated on as such. This is the teaching of Raikva. The language of this chapter is very obscure, and I am not satisfied with the translation.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 56:1 Sayugvan is explained as possessed of a car with yoked horses or oxen. Could it have meant originally, 'yoke-fellow, equal,' as in Rig-veda X, 130, 4? Anquetil renders it by 'semper cum se ipso camelum solutum habens.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 56:2 Instead of adhareyâ h , we must read adhare 'yâ h .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 57:1 It is curious that in a hymn of the Atharva-veda (V, 22, 5, 8) takman, apparently a disease of the skin, is relegated to the Mahâv ri shas, where Raikva dwelt. Roth, Zur Literatur des Veda, p. 36.
